subject: linear_algebra
title: Gauss-Jordan Elimination: Solving Systems of Linear Equations
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to solve a system of linear equations using Gauss-Jordan elimination.
name: Augmented Matrix" },
hints: Start by applying a row operation to eliminate a variable
solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we'll use Gauss-Jordan elimination. Here are the steps:

  1. Write the augmented matrix:

    2. \[\\begin{bmatrix}2&3&7\\1&-2&-3\\end{bmatrix}\]

  2. Apply a row operation to eliminate the y-variable in the first equation:

    3. \[\\begin{bmatrix}1&-1.5&3.5\\0&-4&-10\\end{bmatrix}\]

  3. Repeat this process until we reach reduced row echelon form:

    4. \[\\begin{bmatrix}1&0&7/2\\0&1&5/2\\end{bmatrix}\]

  4. Equate the variables to find the solution:

    5. x = 7/2, y = 5/2

    ",
problemHtml:
Solve the system of linear equations using Gauss-Jordan elimination:

  • 3x + 2y - z = 4
  • x - y + 2z = 1
  • y - 3z = -2

steps.explanation: This is the starting point for our elimination process.

steps.description: Apply a row operation to eliminate a variable
steps.explanation: We're eliminating the z-variable in the first equation.

steps.description: Repeat this process until we reach reduced row echelon form
steps.explanation: We're now in reduced row echelon form, and we can equate the variables to find the solution.

steps.description: Equate the variables to find the solution
steps.explanation: Now that we're in reduced row echelon form, we can solve for x, y, and z.

intuition: Gauss-Jordan elimination is a powerful technique for solving systems of linear equations. By applying row operations to the augmented matrix, we can eliminate variables and reach reduced row echelon form.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Gauss-Jordan Elimination: Solving Systems of Linear Equations
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to solve a system of linear equations using Gauss-Jordan elimination.

problem.statementHtml:
Solve the following system of linear equations:

  • 2x + y - z = 1
  • x - 3y + 2z = -2
  • 4x + 2y + z = 3
hints: Start by applying the same operations to each row
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we'll use Gauss-Jordan elimination. Here are the steps:

  1. Apply the same operation to each row: \frac{1}{2} \cdot R_1
  2. Eliminate y from the second equation by subtracting 3 times R1 from R2:R_2 - 3R_1
  3. Eliminate z from the third equation by adding R1 to R3:R_3 + R_1
  4. Now, we can read off the solution: x = 1, y = 0, and z = 2.

workedExample.problemHtml:
Solve the following system of linear equations:

  • 2x + y - z = 1
  • x - 3y + 2z = -2
  • 4x + 2y + z = 3

steps.description: Apply the same operation to each row
steps.explanation: This helps us get rid of fractions in the next steps.

steps.description: Eliminate y from the second equation
steps.explanation: We're eliminating y by subtracting 3 times R1 from R2.

steps.description: Eliminate z from the third equation
steps.explanation: Now we can eliminate z by adding R1 to R3.
The final answer is x = 1, y = 0, and z = 2.

intuition: Gauss-Jordan elimination helps us solve systems of linear equations by transforming them into upper triangular form.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Gauss-Jordan Elimination: Solving Systems of Linear Equations
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to solve a system of linear equations using Gauss-Jordan elimination.

problem.statementHtml:
Solve the following system of linear equations:

\[\begin{align*} 2x_1 + x_2 &= 3, \\ x_1 - 2x_2 &= -4. \end{align*}\]
hints: Start by applying row operations to the augmented matrix
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we'll use Gauss-Jordan elimination. Here are the steps:

  • Step 1: Swap rows 1 and 2 to make the coefficient of \(x_1\) in the second equation positive.
    • \[\begin{align*} &\swap{1,2} \\ \end{align*}\]
  • Step 2: Add -2 times row 1 to row 2 to make the coefficient of \(x_2\) in the second equation zero.
    • \[\begin{align*} &-2R_1 + R_2 \\ \end{align*}\]
  • Step 3: Add row 1 to row 2 to make the constant term in the second equation positive.
    • \[\begin{align*} &R_1 + R_2 \\ \end{align*}\]
  • Step 4: Divide row 2 by -1 to get a positive coefficient for \(x_2\).
    • \[\begin{align*} &-R_2 \\ \end{align*}\]

    The resulting matrix is in reduced row echelon form, and we can read off the solution:

workedExample.problemHtml:
Solve the following system of linear equations using Gauss-Jordan elimination:

\[\begin{align*} 2x_1 + x_2 &= 3, \\ x_1 - 2x_2 &= -4. \end{align*}\]

steps.description: Swap rows 1 and 2 to make the coefficient of \(x_1\) in the second equation positive.
steps.explanation: This step is necessary because we want to have a positive coefficient for \(x_1\) in the second equation.

steps.description: Add -2 times row 1 to row 2 to make the coefficient of \(x_2\) in the second equation zero.
steps.explanation: This step eliminates the \(x_2\) term from the second equation.

steps.description: Add row 1 to row 2 to make the constant term in the second equation positive.
steps.explanation: This step makes the constant term in the second equation positive.

steps.description: Divide row 2 by -1 to get a positive coefficient for \(x_2\).
steps.explanation: This step gives us a positive coefficient for \(x_2\) in the second equation.

intuition: Gauss-Jordan elimination is a powerful technique for solving systems of linear equations. By applying row operations to the augmented matrix, we can transform it into reduced row echelon form and read off the solution.

subject: linear_algebra
title: Gauss-Jordan Elimination: Solving Systems of Linear Equations
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to solve a system of linear equations using Gauss-Jordan elimination.

hints: Start by applying row operations to get the matrix in reduced row echelon form
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we'll use Gauss-Jordan elimination. Here are the steps:

  1. Apply row operations to get the matrix in reduced row echelon form:
    • \[ \begin{array}{rrr|r} 2 & 3 & -1 & |& 5 \\ -1 & 2 & 3 & |& -3 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 & |& 7 \end{array} \]
    • \[ \begin{array}{rrr|r} 1 & 0.5 & -0.333 & |& 1.1666 \\ 0 & 1 & 1.6667 & |& -2.5 \\ 0 & 0.3333 & 1 & |& 4.3333 \end{array} \]
    • Read off the solution:
      • x = 1.1666
      • y = -2.5
      • z = 4.3333

steps.description: Apply row operations to get the matrix in reduced row echelon form
steps.explanation: We want to get the matrix in reduced row echelon form, which will make it easier to read off the solution
This row operation eliminates the x-term in row 2
This row operation eliminates the z-term in row 3
We can read off the values of x, y, and z from the reduced row echelon form

intuition: Gauss-Jordan elimination is a powerful tool for solving systems of linear equations. By applying row operations to get the matrix in reduced row echelon form, we can easily read off the solution.
visualDescription: A diagram showing the step-by-step process of Gauss-Jordan elimination would be helpful
commonMistakes: Not recognizing when the matrix is in reduced row echelon form
realWorldApplications: Solving systems of linear equations arises in many areas, including machine learning and computer vision
